learning_objectives: Explore the possibility of writing every natural number as a sum of consecutive numbers
Determine which numbers can be written as the sum of consecutive numbers in more than one way
Understand the relationship between odd and even numbers in the context of consecutive sums

content_blocks.text: Anshu is exploring sums of consecutive numbers. He has written the following —
When one of its signs is switched, its value always increases or decreases by an even number! Let us see why.
Consider one of the expressions: a + b – c – d. Replacing +b by – b, we get a – b – c – d.
odd ± odd = even
We have seen that the parity of a + b and a – b is the same, regardless of the parities of a and b.
In short, a ± b have the same parity. By the same argument, a ± b + c and a ± b – c have the same parity.

learning_objectives: Understand the concept of sum of consecutive numbers
Explore the relationship between consecutive numbers and their sums

content_blocks.text: Take any 4 consecutive numbers. For example, 3, 4, 5, and 6. Place ‘+’ and ‘–’ signs in between the numbers.
When 4 consecutive numbers are chosen, no matter how the ‘+’ and ‘–’ signs are placed between them, the resulting expressions always have even parity.

learning_objectives: Understand the concept of parity of sums
Explore the relationship between parity of sums and consecutive numbers

content_blocks.text: Even numbers have a factor of 2. Negative numbers having a factor 2 are also even numbers, for example, – 2, – 4, – 6, and so on.
When 4 consecutive numbers are chosen, no matter how the ‘+’ and ‘–’ signs are placed between them, the resulting expressions always have even parity.
We know that odd ± odd = even, even ± even = even, and odd ± even = odd.

learning_objectives: Understand the concept of parity and its behavior under different operations
Identify even and odd numbers using various methods

content_blocks.text: The parity of a number is its property of being even or odd.
If the difference between two numbers is even, can they have different parities? No! So either both are even or both are odd.
For example, if m = 4 and q = – 9, the expression 4m + 2q becomes 4 × 4 + 2 × (–9) = – 2, which is an even number.
We know 4m is even and 2q is even for any integers m and q. Therefore, their sum will also be even.
For example, if x = 6, then x2 + 2 = 38, and (ii) if x = 3, then x2 + 2 = 11.
In the expression x2 + 2, x2 is even if x is even, and x2 is odd if x is odd.
When is the sum a multiple of 4, and when is it not?
Even numbers can be of two types based on the remainders they leave when divided by 4.

learning_objectives: Identify even numbers using various methods
Understand how parity behaves under different operations

content_blocks.text: We know how to identify even numbers. Without computing them, find out which of the following arithmetic expressions are even.
Using our understanding of how parity behaves under different operations, identify which of the following algebraic expressions give an even number for any integer values for the letter-numbers.
2a + 2b 3g + 5h 4m + 2n 2u – 4v
The expression 4m + 2q will always evaluate to an even number for any integer values of m and q.
For example, if m = 4 and q = – 9, the expression 4m + 2q becomes 4 × 4 + 2 × (–9) = – 2, which is an even number.

learning_objectives: Understand the concept of pairs of even numbers
Identify when the sum of two even numbers is a multiple of 4
To understand when the sum of two even numbers is divisible by 4
To identify patterns and rules for even numbers

content_blocks.text: Take a pair of even numbers. Add them. Is the sum divisible by 4?
Try this with different pairs of even numbers.
When is the sum a multiple of 4, and when is it not?
Is there a general rule or a pattern?
Even numbers can be of two types based on the remainders they leave when divided by 4.
Even numbers that are multiples of 4 leave a remainder of 0 when divided by 4.
Even numbers that are not multiples of 4 leave a remainder 2 when divided by 4.

learning_objectives: To understand when an expression always gives an even number
To identify patterns and rules for even numbers

content_blocks.text: For example, if m = 4 and q = – 9, the expression 4m + 2q becomes 4 × 4 + 2 × (–9) = – 2, which is an even number.
An example and a non-example for when the expression evaluates to an even number — (i) if x = 6, then x2 + 2 = 38, and (ii) if x = 3, then x 2 + 2 = 11.
Similarly, determine and explain which of the other expressions always give even numbers. Write a couple of examples and non-examples, as appropriate, for each expression.

topic_name: When Will Two Even Numbers Add Up to Give a Multiple of 4?
learning_objectives: To understand when the sum of two even numbers is divisible by 4
To identify patterns and rules for even numbers

content_blocks.text: There are three cases to examine: Adding 4p and 4q, Adding 4p and (4q + 2), and Adding (4p + 2) and (4q + 2).
Adding 4p and 4q will always give a multiple of 4.
Adding 4p and (4q + 2) will always give a multiple of 4 because their remainders of 2 add up to 4.
Adding (4p + 2) and (4q + 2) will always give a multiple of 4 because their remainders of 2 add up to 4.

learning_objectives: To understand the relationship between factors and multiples
To identify patterns and rules for factors and multiples

content_blocks.text: We know that the sum of any two multiples of 2 is also a multiple of 2.
If 8 exactly divides two numbers separately, it must exactly divide their sum.
In general, if a divides M and a divides N, then a divides M + N and a divides M – N.

learning_objectives: To understand the concept of multiples of a number
To identify whether a number is a multiple of another number

content_blocks.text: If a divides M and a divides N, then a divides M + N and a divides M – N.
A number 8m divisible by 8 is a multiple of 8.
A number 8m = 8a + 8b divisible by 8 can be a sum of two multiples of 8 or a sum of two non-multiples of 8.
If a number is divisible by 7, then all multiples of that number will be divisible by 7.
Numbers divisible by 7 will have 7 as a factor.
In general, if A is divisible by k, then all multiples of A are divisible by k.
If a number is divisible by 12, then the number is also divisible by all the factors of 12.
Factors of multiples of 12 will include factors of 12.
In general, if A is divisible by k, then A is divisible by all the factors of k.
Numbers divisible by 7k will be divisible by 7 if and only if m is a factor of k.
42 (7 × 6) is divisible by 7 but it is not divisible by 28 (7 × 4).
In general, if A is divisible by k and A is also divisible by m, then A is divisible by the LCM of k and m.
When you add an odd number to an even number we get a multiple of 6.

learning_objectives: Understand the concept of divisibility and remainders
Apply divisibility rules to determine divisibility and remainders

content_blocks.text: In general, if A is divisible by k and A is also divisible by m, then A is divisible by the LCM of k and m. This is because A is a multiple of k and also a multiple of m, so A's prime factorisation should contain the prime factorisation of LCM (k, m).

We know that multiples of 6 are all even Can I write an even and an odd number as 2n and 2n+1 instead? The sum of an odd number and an even number will be an odd number. Therefore, this statement is never true.

Numbers that leave a remainder of 0 when divided by 5 are the multiples of 5. But we want numbers that leave a remainder of 3 when divided by 5. These numbers are 3 more than multiples of 5. Multiples of 5 are of the form 5k. So, numbers that leave a remainder of 3 when divided by 5 are those of the form 5k + 3

Let us consider another expression, 5k – 2, and see the values it takes for different values of k. Numbers that leave a remainder of 3 when k = 1 2 3 4 5 divided by 5 can also be seen as 2 less than multiples of 5; 5k – 2, where k ≥ 1.

The numbers that leave a remainder of 2 when divided by 3 and a remainder of 2 when divided by 4 can be found by considering the LCM of 3 and 4, which is 12. Therefore, the numbers that leave a remainder of 2 when divided by 3 and a remainder of 2 when divided by 4 are those of the form 12k + 2.

learning_objectives: Understand the concept of consecutive numbers
Apply the concept of consecutive numbers to solve problems

content_blocks.text: The sum of four consecutive numbers is 34. What are these numbers?
Suppose p is the greatest of five consecutive numbers. Describe the other four numbers in terms of p.
For each statement below, determine whether it is always true, sometimes true, or never true. Explain your answer. Mention examples and non-examples as appropriate. Justify your claim using algebra.

learning_objectives: Understand the concept of remainders
Apply the concept of remainders to solve problems

content_blocks.text: Find a number that leaves a remainder of 2 when divided by 3 and a remainder of 2 when divided by 4.

The numbers that leave a remainder of 2 when divided by 3 and a remainder of 2 when divided by 4 can be found by considering the LCM of 3 and 4, which is 12. Therefore, the numbers that leave a remainder of 2 when divided by 3 and a remainder of 2 when divided by 4 are those of the form 12k + 2.
Find a number that leaves a remainder of 2 when divided by 3, a remainder of 3 when divided by 4, and a remainder of 4 when divided by 5.

learning_objectives: Understand the divisibility shortcuts for 10, 5, and 2
Explain why the divisibility shortcuts work

content_blocks.text: Divisibility by 10, 5, and 2: If the units digit of a number is ‘0’, then it is divisible by 10.

We can write the general form of a number in the Indian system using a set of letter-numbers. For example, a 5-digit number can be expressed as, edcba denoting e × 10000 + d × 1000 + c × 100 + b × 10 + a.
For example, in the number 4075, d = 4, c = 0, b = 7, and a = 5.
We know that each place value, with the exception of the units place, is a multiple of 10. So, 10b, 100c, … all will be multiples of 10.
Hence, the number will be divisible by 10 if and only if the units digit a is 0.

learning_objectives: Understand the divisibility shortcut for 9
Explain why the divisibility shortcut works

content_blocks.text: A Shortcut for Divisibility by 9: Can you say, without actually calculating, which of these numbers are divisible by 9: 999, 909, 900, 90, 990?
All of them.
Can we say that any number made up of only the digits ‘0’ and ‘9’, in any order, will always be divisible by 9?
Yes, if each digit is either 0 or 9, then each term in its expanded form will be 9 × or 0 × (the ‘ ’ denotes a place value).
But this shortcut alone cannot identify all the multiples of 9.
Unlike the numbers 2, 5, and 10, we cannot identify the multiples of 9 by just looking at the unit’s digit.
99 and 109 are two numbers with 9 as the units digit; but 99 is 9 1 9 1 divisible by 9, while 109 is not.
Is 10 divisible by 9? If not, what is the remainder?
Check the divisibility of other multiples of 10 (10, 20, 30, ...) by 9.
You will notice that for any multiple of 10, the remainder is the same as the number of tens.
Similarly, look at the remainder when the multiples of 100 (100, 200, 300, … ) are divided by 9.
What do you notice?
The remainder is the same as the number of hundreds for any multiple of 100.
Using this observation, find the remainder when 427 is divided by 9.
We see that 427 has 4 hundreds; thus, its corresponding remainder (upon division by 9) would be 4.
427 has 2 tens, and its corresponding remainder would be 2.
We have 7 units also remaining.
Adding all the remainders, we get 4 + 2 + 7 = 13.

learning_objectives: To understand the concept of divisibility by 9
To learn a shortcut method for divisibility by 9
To apply the concept of divisibility by 9 to find remainders
To understand the divisibility rule for 9
To apply the divisibility rule for 9 to find whether a number is divisible by 9

content_blocks.text: Unlike the numbers 2, 5, and 10, we cannot identify the multiples of 9 by just looking at the unit’s digit.
99 and 109 are two numbers with 9 as the units digit; but 99 is 9 1 9 1 divisible by 9, while 109 is not.
Is 10 divisible by 9? If not, what is the remainder? Check the divisibility of other multiples of 10 (10, 20, 30, ...) by 9.
You will notice that for any multiple of 10, the remainder is the same as the number of tens.
Similarly, look at the remainder when the multiples of 100 (100, 200, 300, … ) are divided by 9. What do you notice?
The remainder is the same as the number of hundreds for any multiple of 100.
Using this observation, find the remainder when 427 is divided by 9.
We see that 427 has 4 hundreds; thus, its corresponding remainder (upon division by 9) would be 4. 427 has 2 tens, and its corresponding remainder would be 2. We have 7 units also remaining.

A number is divisible by 9 if and only if the sum of its digits is divisible by 9. Also, we can add the digits of a number repeatedly till a single digit is obtained. This single digit is the remainder when the number is divided by 9.
For example, to find the remainder of 7309 when divided by 9, we can just add all the digits — 7 + 3 + 0 + 9 — to get 19.
This is a multiple of 9 So, we need to just consider this part This means that the number 7309 is 19 more than some multiple of 9.

The digits 1 and 9 can further be added to get 1 + 9 = 10. Now, we can say that 7309 is 10 more than a multiple of 9. And repeating this step for the number 10, we get the remainder to be 1 + 0 = 1, meaning 7309 is 1 more than a multiple of 9.
A number is divisible by 9 if and only if the sum of its digits is divisible by 9.
Also, we can add the digits of a number repeatedly till a single digit is obtained. This single digit is the remainder when the number is divided by 9.
Look at each of the following statements. Which are correct and why?
(i) If a number is divisible by 9, then the sum of its digits is divisible by 9.
Math Talk (ii) If the sum of the digits of a number is divisible by 9, then the number is divisible by 9.
(iii) If a number is not divisible by 9, then the sum of its digits is not divisible by 9.
Figure it Out 1. Find, without dividing, whether the following numbers are divisible by 9.
2. Find the smallest multiple of 9 with no odd digits.
3. Find the multiple of 9 that is closest to the number 6000.
4. How many multiples of 9 are there between the numbers 4300 and 4400?
A Shortcut for Divisibility by 3 We know that all the multiples of 9 are also multiples of 3.
That is, if a number is divisible by 9, it will also be divisible by 3. However, there are other multiples of 3 that are not multiples of 9 for example — 15, 33, and 87.
The shortcut to find the divisibility by 3 is similar to the method for 9.
A number is divisible by 9 if the sum of its digits is divisible by 9.
If a number is not divisible by 9, then the sum of its digits is not divisible by 9.
Find, without dividing, whether the following numbers are divisible by 9: (i) 123 (ii) 405 (iii) 8888 (iv) 93547 (v) 358095
The shortcut to find the divisibility by 9 is similar to the method for 3. A number is divisible by 9 if the sum of its digits is divisible by 9.

learning_objectives: To understand the shortcut for divisibility by 3
To apply the shortcut for divisibility by 3 to find whether a number is divisible by 3

content_blocks.text: A number is divisible by 3 if the sum of its digits is divisible by 3.
The shortcut to find the divisibility by 3 is similar to the method for 9. A number is divisible by 3 if the sum of its digits is divisible by 3.
Using these observations, can you tell whether the number 462 is divisible by 11?

learning_objectives: To understand the shortcut for divisibility by 11
To apply the shortcut for divisibility by 11 to find whether a number is divisible by 11
To learn how to apply the shortcut to find the remainder when a number is divided by 11

content_blocks.text: A number is divisible by 11 if the difference between the sum of digits at odd places and the sum of digits at even places is 0 or a multiple of 11.
The shortcut for 11 is also based on checking the remainders with place value. Let us see how.
Steps Purpose Example for the Number 320185
A Shortcut for Divisibility by 11 Interestingly, the shortcut for 11 is also based on checking the remainders with place value. Let us see how.

We saw that the place values alternate as 1 more and 1 less than a multiple of 11. Using this observation, Steps Purpose Example for the Number 320185 1. Add the digits of place values which are 1 more (than a multiple of 11), i.e., place values corresponding to 1, 100, 10000, and so on. Total excess, 2 + 1 + 5 = 8.
2. Add the digits of place values which are 1 short (than a multiple of 11), i.e., place values corresponding to 3, 10, 10000, and so on. Total short, 3 + 0 + 8 = 11.

Steps to follow Example for the number 328105 1. Place alternating ‘+’ and ‘–’ signs before every digit –3 + 2 – 8 + 1 – 0 + 5 2. Evaluate the expression. –3 + 2 – 8 + 1 – 0 + 5 = – 3 3. The result denotes the remainder obtained when the number is divided by 11.

learning_objectives: To understand how to check divisibility by 6
To learn how to apply the shortcut to find the remainder when a number is divided by 6

content_blocks.text: How can we find out if a number is divisible by 6? Will checking its divisibility by its factors 2 and 3 work?
Use the shortcuts for 2 and 3 on these numbers and divide each number by 6 to verify — 38, 225, 186, 64.

Learn a shortcut to check divisibility by 24

content_blocks.text: To check for the divisibility by 24, we can instead check for the divisibility by 3 and divisibility by 8.
Explain using prime factorisation why checking divisibility by 3 and 8 works for checking divisibility by 24, but checking divisibility by 4 and 6 is not sufficient for checking divisibility by 24.
Determining divisibility by 24 by checking divisibility by 4 and by 6 does not work. For example, the number 12 is divisible by both 4 and 6, but not by 24.
For example, the number 12 is divisible by both 4 and 6, but not by 24.

Understand the concept of digital roots
Learn how to calculate digital roots

content_blocks.text: Take a number. Add its digits repeatedly till you get a single-digit number. This single-digit number is called the digital root of the number.
For example, the digital root of the number 489710 will be
For example, the digital root of the number 489710 will be 2 (4 + 8 + 9 + 7 + 1 + 0 = 29, 2 + 9 = 11, 1 + 1 = 2).
What property do you think this digital root will have? Recall that we did this while finding the divisibility shortcut for 9.

content_blocks.text: Let us now try solving some cryptarithms involving multiplication.
(v) PQ × 8 = RS. Guna says, “Oh, this means a 2-digit number multiplied by 8 should give another 2-digit number.
12 × 8 = 96 fits all the conditions”. Can PQ be 13? Think.
It is not possible because 13 × 8 = 104. For all 2-digit numbers greater than 12, the product with 8 is a 3-digit number.
(vi) Try this now: GH × H = 9K.
This means a 2-digit number multiplied by a 1-digit number gives another 2-digit number in the 90s.
(vii) Here is one more: BYE × 6 = RAY.
Anshu says, “Since the product is a 3-digit number, B can’t be 2 or more.
We can solve cryptarithms using patterns, properties, and reasoning related to numbers and operations.

learning_objectives: Understand the properties of divisibility
Apply the properties to solve problems

content_blocks.text: If a is divisible by b, then all multiples of a are divisible by b.
If a is divisible by b, then a is divisible by all the factors of b.
If a divides m and a divides n, then a divides m + n and m – n.
If a is divisible by b and is also divisible by c, then a is divisible by the LCM of b and c.
We explored and learnt various properties of divisibility—
• If a is divisible by b, then all multiples of a are divisible by b.
• If a is divisible by b, then a is divisible by all the factors of b.
• If a divides m and a divides n, then a divides m + n and m – n.
• If a is divisible by b and is also divisible by c, then a is divisible by the LCM of b and c.

learning_objectives: Understand the shortcuts to check divisibility by 3, 9, and 11
Apply the shortcuts to solve problems

content_blocks.text: We learnt shortcuts to check divisibility by 3, 9 and 11, and why they work.

learning_objectives: Understand the rules of Navakankari
Apply the rules to play the game

content_blocks.text: Navakankari, also known as Sālu Mane Āṭa, Chār-Pār, or Navkakri, is a traditional Indian board game that is the same as ‛Nine Men’s Morris’ or ‛Mills in the West’.
It is a strategy game for two players where the goal is to form lines of three pawns to eliminate the opponent’s pawns or block their movement.
Gameplay: Each player starts with 9 pawns. The players take turns in placing their pawns on the marked intersections. An intersection can have at most one pawn.
Once all the pawns are placed, the players take turns to move one of their pawns to adjacent empty intersections to form lines of three.
A player wins if the opponent has less than 3 pawns or is unable to make a move.

learning_objectives: To understand the concept of making moves in games
To learn how to make strategic moves

content_blocks.text: A move is a step taken in a game. It is a deliberate action taken by a player to change the state of the game.
For example, in a game of chess, a player can make a move by moving a pawn from one square to another.
